latest news.eng_title: Seven tips for Harris to win her debate with Trump
latest news.summary: To win her debate with Trump, Kamala Harris should consider the following tips. Trump's strengths in the 2016 presidential debate included his ability to perform and connect with the audience, as seen when he said, 'Because you'd be in jail.' However, the circumstances of that debate, such as live mics and a live audience, will not be present in the upcoming debate. Harris will have a more controlled environment, with limited time for answers and rebuttals, and will be confined to her podium. Despite this, Harris can still learn from Trump's performance and adapt her strategy to effectively counter his tactics.
latest news.title: Seven tips for Harris to win her debate with Trump

latest news.eng_title: How will Harris debate Trump? Five key moments offer insight
latest news.summary: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump will face off in their first presidential debate on Tuesday, with Harris looking to deliver on her promise to prosecute the case against Trump. Harris has a history of using her sense of humor to undercut opponents, as seen in her 2016 Senate debate against Loretta Sanchez, where she effectively undercut Sanchez with a simple retort. Harris has also shown her prosecutorial skills in Senate hearings, such as her questioning of Jeff Sessions and Brett Kavanaugh. However, Harris has also displayed vulnerabilities, such as her tendency to avoid specifics when discussing policy, as seen in her CNN interview with Dana Bash. Trump has reason to be concerned, but Harris will need to address her vulnerabilities in order to succeed in the debate. 'So there's a clear difference between the candidates in this race,' Harris said, 'I think you're thinking of someone, and you don't want to tell us,' and 'You know, there was a little girl in California who was part of the second class to integrate her public schools, and she was bussed to school every day. And that little girl was me,' are examples of Harris's effective questioning and ability to connect with voters.
latest news.title: How will Harris debate Trump? Five key moments offer insight

latest news.eng_title: Harris Prepares for Debate Against Trump with Strong Strategy
latest news.summary: Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris is preparing for the upcoming debate against Republican candidate Donald Trump with a strong strategy. Harris is rehearsing her answers with a team of advisors at a historic hotel in Pittsburgh, focusing on improving her responses to Trump's potential questions. Harris is also preparing to counter Trump's points by writing down her ideas and responses on cards. In contrast, Trump has downplayed the importance of preparation, saying that he will rely on his instincts during the debate. Trump has cited the example of boxer Mike Tyson, who said 'everyone has a plan until they get hit in the face.' Trump plans to use a surprise approach during the debate, responding to situations as they arise. Harris, on the other hand, will focus on exposing Trump's character and revealing his lack of seriousness about the presidency. She will also highlight his 'criminal record' and the various lawsuits he has faced over the years, according to various American media outlets. The final decision will be left to the voters and viewers, especially since the two candidates are tied in polls in key states, according to the latest surveys.
latest news.title: مناظرة الثلاثاء.. هاريس تتدرب وترامب يستعين بمايك تايسون

latest news.eng_title: Harris's top takedown moments ahead of Trump debate: 'I'm speaking' - Washington Examiner
latest news.summary: Vice President Kamala Harris is set to face off against former President Donald Trump in a debate on September 10. Harris has a history of delivering memorable one-liners and zingers in past debates, including 'I'm speaking,' which she used six times against former Vice President Mike Pence in 2020. She also used this phrase in non-debate settings, such as when protesters tried to interrupt her during a campaign speech in Michigan. Harris's second-most famous debate moment came in 2019 when she knocked President Joe Biden for his opposition to busing as a way to desegregate schools in the 1970s, saying 'There was a little girl in California who was part of the second class to integrate her public schools, and she was bused to school every day. That little girl was me.' Harris has also grilled future Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh and Attorney General William Barr during past debates, using phrases like 'Can you think of any laws that give government the power to make decisions about the male body?' and 'Sir, I'm asking a question.' However, Harris is also well-remembered for being on the receiving end of a zinger from former Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-HI) in 2019, who criticized Harris's record as a prosecutor and laughed when asked if she'd ever smoked marijuana herself.
latest news.title: Harris's top takedown moments ahead of Trump debate: 'I'm speaking' - Washington Examiner

latest news.eng_title: Harris's top takedown moments ahead of Trump debate: ‘I'm speaking'
latest news.summary: Vice President Kamala Harris is set to debate former President Donald Trump on September 10 in Philadelphia. Harris has a history of delivering memorable one-liners and zingers in past debates. Some of her top takedowns include 'I'm speaking', which she used six times against former Vice President Mike Pence in 2020, and 'That little girl was me', which she used to describe her experience as a child who was bused to school to integrate her public schools. Harris has also used one-liners to cut through chaos and make a point, such as 'America does not want to witness a food fight, they want to know how we're going to put food on their table.' Harris has also grilled Trump appointees, including Brett Kavanaugh and William Barr, and has used her questioning to make a point about women's rights and government overreach. Harris's past debate performances offer clues to how she might take on Trump in their upcoming debate.
latest news.title: Harris's top takedown moments ahead of Trump debate: ‘I'm speaking'

latest news.eng_title: Kamala Harris has some debate moves. I know. I moderated her last one.
latest news.summary: Susan Page, the Washington Bureau chief of USA TODAY, moderated the 2020 vice-presidential debate between Kamala Harris and Mike Pence. Harris held her own against Pence, displaying her command as a prosecutor and discipline to stick to her talking points. She effectively used the phrase 'Mr. Vice President, I'm speaking' to interrupt Pence when he tried to speak out of turn. Harris has improved her debating skills since the 2020 election cycle, where she struggled with big issues like Medicare-for-all. She has been sharper and more energetic at campaign rallies, with an ability to needle Donald Trump with humor. The debate showed Harris' ability to handle Trump's style of debating, which could be an advantage in the upcoming presidential debate.
latest news.title: Kamala Harris has some debate moves. I know. I moderated her last one.

latest news.eng_title: Harris and Trump are getting ready for Tuesday's debate in sharply different ways
latest news.summary: Vice President Kamala Harris is preparing for Tuesday's presidential debate by focusing on crafting crisp two-minute answers, according to the debate's rules. She has been working with aides since Thursday and has chosen a venue that allows her to interact with swing-state voters. In contrast, Donald Trump is gearing up for the debate in a different way, setting up a showdown that reflects their distinct approaches to big moments. 'The vice president is cloistered in a historic hotel in downtown Pittsburgh where she can focus on honing crisp two-minute answers, per the debate's rules,' and 'She's been working with aides since Thursday and chose a venue that allows the Democratic nominee the option of mingling with swing-state voters.'
latest news.title: Harris and Trump are getting ready for Tuesday's debate in sharply different ways

latest news.eng_title: Trump says agreement reached for debate with Harris on Sept. 10
latest news.summary: Former President Donald Trump announced that an agreement has been reached for a debate with Vice President Kamala Harris on ABC News on Sept. 10. However, Harris' campaign has yet to officially confirm the agreement. The debate commission has agreed to mute microphones when a candidate is not speaking, a condition that was also in place for the June debate between Trump and President Joe Biden. Harris' campaign has accused Trump's campaign of gaming the system to protect their candidate, while Trump's campaign has accused Harris' campaign of seeking unfair advantages. Trump said, 'I have reached an agreement with Radical Left Democrats for a Debate with Comrade Kamala Harris.' Trump's spokesman, Jason Miller, stated that Trump had 'accepted the ABC debate under the exact same terms as the CNN debate.' Harris' spokesman, Brian Fallon, responded, 'Trump's handlers prefer the muted microphone because they don't think their candidate can act presidential for 90 minutes on his own.'
latest news.title: Trump says agreement reached for debate with Harris on Sept. 10

news knowledge.eng_title: Trump Reveals Debate Strategy: Letting Harris Speak
news knowledge.summary: Donald Trump has announced his strategy for the upcoming debate with Kamala Harris, stating that he will let her speak and not interrupt her. 'I'm going to let her talk', Trump said during a Fox News interview in Pennsylvania. 'Debates are interesting, you can go with all the strategy you want, but you have to feel it out'. He also expressed concerns about the fairness of ABC, the network hosting the debate. 'I hope they're fair', he said. The debate, scheduled for September 10 in Philadelphia, will be the first between Harris and Trump. Harris's campaign has accepted the debate rules, but expressed concerns about the microphone silencing rule, which they believe will favor Trump. Despite the concerns, they have agreed to the rules, including the microphone silencing. The debate will be moderated by David Muir and Linsey Davis and will be held without an audience at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia.
news knowledge.title: Trump adelanta su estrategia para el próximo debate con Harris

news knowledge.eng_title: Trump on Upcoming Debate with Kamala Harris: 'I'll Let Her Speak'
news knowledge.summary: Former US President Donald Trump stated that he would 'let her speak' during his next debate with Vice President Kamala Harris. Trump told Fox News host Sean Hannity, 'You and I had the same discussion when Biden was president, and I let him speak. I'll let her speak.' Trump expressed concerns about the fairness of the debate, saying 'It depends on ABC, will they be fair or not?' Trump also claimed that Harris' team wanted to take notes and have a table, but he opposed it. The ABC News rules prohibit note-taking and the candidates will be seated behind podiums. Trump also made an unsubstantiated claim that Harris' team would receive the questions in advance.
news knowledge.title: Trump sobre o próximo debate com Kamala: 'Vou deixá-la falar'

news knowledge.eng_title: "I'm Going To Let Her Talk": Donald Trump On Debate With Kamala Harris
news knowledge.summary: Donald Trump has announced that he will allow his opponent, Kamala Harris, to speak without interruption during their presidential debate next week, a shift from his usual combative style. Trump said, 'I'm going to let her talk.' The debate, hosted by ABC News, has been the center of a row over the rules for microphones, with Trump claiming the network is biased in favor of Harris. The rules state that microphones will be 'live only for the candidate whose turn it is to speak and muted when the time belongs to another candidate.' Harris' team has expressed concerns that the muted microphones will disadvantage her and shield Trump from direct engagement. The debate is the first and potentially only opportunity for the two candidates to spar in person in a very close contest, with only two months until Election Day.
news knowledge.title: "I'm Going To Let Her Talk": Donald Trump On Debate With Kamala Harris

news knowledge.eng_title: Trump says his debate strategy is to give Harris room to speak - Times of India
news knowledge.summary: Donald Trump has announced that he will let Kamala Harris speak without interruption during their upcoming presidential debate. This shift comes as the candidates prepare for a crucial face-off hosted by ABC News in Philadelphia. Trump's strategy is to give Harris room to speak, a change from previous debates where he was known to interrupt his opponents. The debate is pivotal for swaying Pennsylvania's swing state voters.
news knowledge.title: Trump says his debate strategy is to give Harris room to speak - Times of India

news knowledge.eng_title: Trump Says His Debate Strategy Is to Give Harris Room to Speak
news knowledge.summary: Donald Trump has announced that he plans to allow his opponent, Kamala Harris, to speak without interruption during their presidential debate next week. Trump said, 'I'm going to let her talk,' and added that debates are 'interesting' and that one has to 'feel it out.' This is a shift for Trump, who has built a career on combative exchanges. The debate, hosted by ABC News, is the next big test for the two candidates and presents risks for both Harris and Trump. The debate rules have been a point of contention, with Harris' camp seeking to keep both candidates' microphones live throughout the broadcast and Trump's team pushing for them to be muted when they are not answering questions. The debate will take place in Philadelphia, a critical swing state, and is the first and potentially only opportunity for the two candidates to spar in-person in a very close contest.
news knowledge.title: Trump Says His Debate Strategy Is to Give Harris Room to Speak

news knowledge.eng_title: Harris admits it: Wants open debate mics to sting Trump like Pence - Washington Examiner
news knowledge.summary: Kamala Harris has admitted that she wants open debate mics to 'sting' Donald Trump, similar to her 'I'm speaking' moments in the 2020 debate with Mike Pence. Harris is hoping to create more notable moments at next week's debate, which will be hosted by ABC News. Despite the Trump campaign and ABC News stating that the fight over open microphones is over and they will be shut off for the candidate not speaking, Team Harris is still pushing for them to be turned on. The media is poised to attack Trump as a bully, similar to how they did in the 2016 debate with Hillary Clinton.
news knowledge.title: Harris admits it: Wants open debate mics to sting Trump like Pence - Washington Examiner

news knowledge.eng_title: 'I'm speaking': Kamala Harris snaps back at pro-Palestine hecklers
news knowledge.summary: Vice President Kamala Harris shut down pro-Palestine hecklers at her Michigan rally, warning them that if they continued, Donald Trump would win the election. Harris invoked her 2020 debate line, 'I'm speaking,' and said, 'Everyone's voice matters, but I am speaking now, I am speaking now.' She then attacked Trump's policies, saying he plans to give tax breaks to billionaires, cut social security and Medicare, and surrender the fight against the climate crisis. Harris's popularity has been growing, with new polls suggesting she is gaining support since President Joe Biden dropped out of the running for re-election.
news knowledge.title: 'I'm speaking': Kamala Harris snaps back at pro-Palestine hecklers

news knowledge.eng_title: 'I'm speaking': Watch Kamala Harris stare down hecklers at Michigan rally
news knowledge.summary: Vice President Kamala Harris stood firm against hecklers at a Detroit rally, saying 'I'm speaking' and delivering a withering stare. The protesters, believed to be pro-Palestinian, were chanting about 'genocide' in reference to the Israeli counteroffensive in Gaza. Harris, who has expressed 'serious concerns' about Israel's stance, told the protesters 'If you want Donald Trump to win, then say that. Otherwise, I'm speaking.' The crowd cheered and chanted 'We're not going back' as the protesters were escorted out of the venue.
news knowledge.title: 'I'm speaking': Watch Kamala Harris stare down hecklers at Michigan rally

news knowledge.eng_title: 'I'm speaking': Kamala Harris shuts down hecklers to thunderous applause
news knowledge.summary: Vice President Kamala Harris was confronted by hecklers at a Detroit rally, but she effectively silenced them with a memorable line, 'You know what, if you want Donald Trump to win, say that. Otherwise, I'm speaking.' The crowd erupted in cheers, reminiscent of a similar moment in the 2020 vice presidential debates. Harris' line has become an iconic phrase, resonating with women who struggle to be heard. This incident follows a pattern of protesters disrupting events, including President Joe Biden's rallies, driven by anger over the US position on Israel.
news knowledge.title: 'I'm speaking': Kamala Harris shuts down hecklers to thunderous applause

news knowledge.eng_title: Kamala Harris Invites Donald Trump to Debate: 'Say It to My Face'
news knowledge.summary: US Vice President Kamala Harris has invited former President Donald Trump to a presidential debate, saying 'If you have something to say to me, tell me to my face.' Harris made the call during an election event in Atlanta, Georgia, where she addressed a crowd of 10,000 people. She emphasized that the momentum in the presidential campaign is shifting and urged Trump to face her in the debate. Harris used the opportunity to pressure Trump, who has shown reservations about participating in the second presidential debate scheduled for September 10. 'The momentum in this campaign is changing and there are signs that Donald Trump is feeling it (...) I hope you reconsider meeting me on the debate stage, because, as the saying goes: if you have something to say to me, say it to my face.' Harris said during her speech in Atlanta. Harris began her speech by highlighting her professional background, focusing on her experience as a senator and attorney general. She emphasized her work in confronting criminals and her knowledge of Trump, arguing that her experience prepares her to lead the country. 'In those roles, I faced all kinds of criminals: predators who abused women; scammers who scammed consumers; cheaters who broke the rules for their own benefit. So listen to me when I say that I know Donald Trump.' Harris said. The speech also included a review of her policy proposals, including key issues such as immigration, inflation, access to abortion, expansion of voting rights, and the ban on assault weapons. During the event, Harris received a warm reception from the audience, who showed their enthusiasm with applause and cheers. The candidate has raised $200 million and has around 170,000 volunteers in her campaign. Additionally, her event in Atlanta included musical performances by rapper Quavo and singer Megan Thee Stallion, aimed at capturing the support of the African American voter, crucial to winning in Georgia.
news knowledge.title: 'Si tienes algo que decirme, dimelo en la cara': Kamala Harris invita a Donald Trump a debate
